ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to learn and apply Chinese in this course. Chen Lao Shi makes the class very fun while teaching Chinese.

My speaking and writing skills in Chinese developed tremendously by taking this course. Having previously taken Chinese classes in high school which was less fulfilling, the Chinese program at Yale ensures that there is growth in speaking and writing skills by having interactive classes 4 weekdays a week, and an asynchronous day.
increased chinese vocabulary and grammer structures, understanding of chinese culture and how it is similar/different from the us
A lot of reading and writing Chinese and then more practice with speaking and listening
This class really helps with full immersion into the Chinese culture and language. Wonderful course and genuinely helps you solidify your current understanding of Chinese a lot.
Chinese grammar, reading/writing ability. Also verbal presentation.
Reading and Writing Abilities in Chinese.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The class is very well-structured, with a set daily schedule established from the beginning of the semester. There are daily quizzes (reading comprehension, Pinyin, and  which ensures that each chapter is understood . The quizzes and homework decrease towards the end of the semester, when a foundation is consolidated. The unit (3 chapter) exams are much better than having midterms/finals. The majority of the class is spent reading the current chapter, practicing sentence structures/vocabulary, and verbally responding to the teacher using learned sentence structures. Overall, it is a class that improves your weaknesses, whether that be speaking, reading, or writing. There is also plenty of help offered by Chen LaoShi and the Tutorial Teaching Fellow.
Weakness: I wish there were more group projects earlier in the semester, but there would be plenty in the second half of the semester, which are great develop a class bond while practicing Chinese.

strengths: really clearly and helpfully organized, holds students accountable for learning the language on a daily basis, great opportunities to practice speaking and writing chinese

weaknesses: none, except for the asynchronous class on thursday can sometimes feel like an unnecessary break in the flow of the class
Maybe a little more group projects instead of quizzes

Strengths: I walked away gaining a huge improvement in my Chinese speaking and writing
Weakness: Heavy workload, but ultimately worth it.
Well organized and effectively structured. A good amount of busy work and high time commitment.

Strength: Quick acquisition of literary skills 
Weakness: Lack of Collaborative activities or discussion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! The class is very engaging with the smaller class size. The class definitely improved my Chinese reading, writing, and speaking skills significantly. There is a lot of help, feedback, and suggestions offered throughout the semester to make improvement. The amount of time/effort you put into the class is what you get out of it!
yes! i feel increasingly confident in my ability to speak and read/write chinese, and prof. chen is the best
Yes it is a good course to learn how to read and write Chinese

I would 100% recommend this to another student! The friendships and knowledge you walk away from this class are incredible. You not only learn about the language, but about the Chinese culture as well.
Yes - great way to learn/re-learn Chinese.
Yes. It is a good introduction if you are comfortable with verbal and need to work on writing.
